statement.p: The gas tank in Rosa's Toyota Prius holds 11 gallons, and she gets 48 miles to the gallon.

li.p: Write an equation for the amount of gasoline, g, left in the tank after Rosa has driven for d miles.
Find the intercepts of the graph.
The d-intercept is .
The g-intercept is .
What do they tell us about the problem situation?
The d-intercept gives:
The g-intercept: gives

hint.p: Rewrite the sentence with mathematical symbols: \small{(\text{gasoline left}) = (\text{gallons in full tank}) - (\text{mileage rate}) \times (\text{miles driven})}

li.p: (528,0): After Rosa drives 528 miles, the tank will be empty.
(0,11): The tank has 11 gallons before Rosa begins driving.

statement.p: The gas tank in Rosas Toyota Prius holds 11 gallons, and she gets 48 miles to the gallon.

li.p: Write an equation for the amount of gasoline, g\text{,} left in the tank after Rosa has driven for d miles.
Find the intercepts of the graph.
The d-intercept is .
The g-intercept is .
What do they tell us about the problem situation?
The d-intercept gives:
miles Rosa can drive before the tank is empty
miles to the next gas stop
gallons of gasoline before Rosa begins driving
gallons of gasoline per mile of driving
The g-intercept: gives
miles Rosa can drive before the tank is empty
miles to the next gas stop
gallons of gasoline before Rosa begins driving
gallons of gasoline per mile of driving

hint.p: Rewrite the sentence with mathematical symbols:

li.p: (528,0)\text{:} After Rosa drives 528 miles, the tank will be empty.
(0,11)\text{:} The tank has 11 gallons before Rosa begins driving.

li.p: Any equation whose graph is a straight line.
Set x=0 and solve for y.

statement.p: The manager at Breadbasket Bakery has $120 to spend on advertising. An ad in the local newspaper costs $15, and posters cost $4 each. She decides to buy x ads and y posters. Write an equation relating x and y.

hint.p: Use the general form for a linear equation. What is the total amount of money the manager will spend?

statement.p: The manager at Breadbasket Bakery has $120 to spend on advertising. An ad in the local newspaper costs $15, and posters cost $4 each. She decides to buy x ads and y posters. Write an equation relating x and y\text{.}

hint.p: Use the general form for a linear equation. What is the total amount of money the manager will spend?

setup.pg-code: $which1 = RadioButtons( ["Make a table of values and plot the points.", "Extend the line until it crosses both axes.", "Solve for \(y\) in terms of \(x\).", "Plot the points where \(x=0\) and where \(y=0\), then draw the line through them."], 3, );

statement.p: Describe the intercept method of graphing a linear equation.

solution.p: Plot the intercepts (that is, the points where x=0 and where y=0), then draw the line through them.

statement.p: Describe the intercept method of graphing a linear equation.

li.p: Make a table of values and plot the points.
Extend the line until it crosses both axes.
Solve for y in terms of x.
Plot the points where x=0 and where y=0, then draw the line through them.

solution.p: Plot the intercepts (that is, the points where x=0 and where y=0), then draw the line through them.

statement.p: Find the x- and y-intercepts of the equation in Practice 3 (Notebook1.2.10), and use the intercepts to graph the equation. Enter each intercept as an ordered pair.
The x-intercept is .
The y-intercept is .

hint.p: Choose convenient scales for the x- and y-axes.

solution.p: We find the x-intercept by setting y=0 and solving for x to learn that x=8\text{,} so the x-intercept is {\left(8,0\right)}\text{.}
We find the y-intercept by setting x=0 and solving for y to learn that y=30\text{,} so the y-intercept is {\left(0,30\right)}\text{.}
A graph is below.

webwork-reps.pg:
####################################### ### Generated from PreTeXt source ### on 2020-03-17T13:12:35-07:00 ### ### https://pretextbook.org ### ####################################### ## DBsubject() ## DBchapter() ## DBsection() ## Level() ## KEYWORDS() ## TitleText1() ## EditionText1() ## AuthorText1() ## Section1(not reported) ## Problem1(1.2.13) ## Author() ## Institution() ## Language(en-US)
DOCUMENT();
############################################################ # Load Macros ############################################################ loadMacros( "PGstandard.pl", "MathObjects.pl", "PGML.pl", "AnswerFormatHelp.pl", "PGcourse.pl", );
############################################################ # Header ############################################################ COMMENT('Authored in PreTeXt PreTeXt'); TEXT(beginproblem());
############################################################ # PG Setup ############################################################ Context("Point"); $x0=8; $y0=30; $xint = Point($x0,0); $yint = Point(0,$y0);
############################################################ # Body ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML Find the [`x`]\- and [`y`]-intercepts of the equation in Practice 3 (Notebook[$NBSP]*1.2.10), and use the intercepts to graph the equation. Enter each intercept as an ordered pair.
The [`x`]-intercept is [_]{$xint}{4}.
The [`y`]-intercept is [_]{$yint}{4}.
END_PGML
############################################################ # Hint ############################################################ #Set value of $showHint in PGcourse.pl for course-wide attempt threshhold for revealing hints
BEGIN_PGML_HINT Choose convenient scales for the [`x`]\- and [`y`]-axes.
END_PGML_HINT
############################################################ # Solution ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML_SOLUTION We find the [`x`]-intercept by setting [`y=0`] and solving for [`x`] to learn that [`x=[$x0]\text{,}`] so the [`x`]-intercept is [`[$xint]\text{.}`]
We find the [`y`]-intercept by setting [`x=0`] and solving for [`y`] to learn that [`y=[$y0]\text{,}`] so the [`y`]-intercept is [`[$yint]\text{.}`]
A graph is below.
END_PGML_SOLUTION
############################################################ # End Problem ############################################################
ENDDOCUMENT();

li.p: Solve the equation 150x + 50y = 3000 for y in terms of x.
Write the equation y = 0.15x - 3.8 in general linear form with integer coefficients.

Write the equation y = 0.15x - 3.8 in general linear form with integer coefficients.

solution.p: x=-3 and x=1

solution.p: x=-3 and x=1

statement.p: Find some more solutions of the equation -3x + 4y = 24 and complete the table of values:
Find some more solutions of the equation -3x + 4y = 24 and complete the table of values:

li.p: All the solutions of a linear equation in two variables lie on a straight line.
The equation -3x + 4y = 24 is a linear equation.
The graph of an equation in two variables is a picture of its solutions.
If a point lies on the graph of an equation, it is a solution of the equation.

True

li.p:
Use the graph of y = 30 - 8x to solve the equation 30 - 8x = 50.Follow the steps:
Step 1: Locate the point P on the graph with y = 50.
Step 2: Find the x-coordinate of your point P.
Verify your solution algebraically.
Verify your solution algebraically.

Use the graph of y = 30 - 8x to solve the equation 30 - 8x \lt 14. Follow the steps:
Step 1: Locate the point P on the graph with y = 14.
Step 2: Find the x-coordinate of the point P.
Step 3: Which points on the graph have y \lt 14? Mark them on the graph.
Step 4: Find the x-coordinates of the points in Step 3. Mark them all on the x-axis.
Verify your solution algebraically.

statement.p: Solution:

li.p: Verify your solution algebraically.

webwork-reps.pg:
####################################### ### Generated from PreTeXt source ### on 2020-03-17T13:12:35-07:00 ### ### https://pretextbook.org ### ####################################### ## DBsubject() ## DBchapter() ## DBsection() ## Level() ## KEYWORDS() ## TitleText1() ## EditionText1() ## AuthorText1() ## Section1(not reported) ## Problem1(1.3.22) ## Author() ## Institution() ## Language(en-US)
DOCUMENT();
############################################################ # Load Macros ############################################################ loadMacros( "PGstandard.pl", "MathObjects.pl", "PGML.pl", "niceTables.pl", "AnswerFormatHelp.pl", "PGcourse.pl", );
############################################################ # Header ############################################################ COMMENT('Authored in PreTeXt PreTeXt'); TEXT(beginproblem());
############################################################ # PG Setup ############################################################ Context("Point"); $answer = Point("(-2.5,-122)");
############################################################ # Body ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML a. Graph the equation [`y=32x-42`] in the window:
[@DataTable( [ [[PGML('Xmin[`=-4.7 \qquad`]'),], [PGML('Xmax[`=4.7 \qquad`]'),], [PGML('Xscl[`=1 \qquad`]'),], ], [[PGML('Ymin[`=-250 \qquad`]'),], [PGML('Ymax[`=50 \qquad`]'),], [PGML('Yscl[`=25 \qquad`]'),], ], ], align => 'lll', center => 0, );@]*
a. Use the Trace feature to find the point that has [`y`]-coordinate [`-122\text{.}`]
[_]{$answer}{8} Enter an ordered pair.
a. Verify your answer algebraically by substituting your [`x`]-value into the equation.
END_PGML
############################################################ # Solution ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML_SOLUTION a. A graph is below.
a. [`(-2.5,-122) `]
a. [`\newcommand\degree[0]{^{\circ}}\newcommand\Ccancel[2][black]{\renewcommand\CancelColor{\color{#1}}\cancel{#2}}\newcommand{\alert}[1]{\boldsymbol{\color{magenta}{#1}}}\newcommand{\blert}[1]{\boldsymbol{\color{blue}{#1}}}\blert{-122} = 32(\alert{-2.5}) - 42`]
END_PGML_SOLUTION
############################################################ # End Problem ############################################################
ENDDOCUMENT();

hint.p: Start by finding $9.50 on the Cost (vertical axis). Then find the point on the graph with C-coordinate $9.50. Finally, find the t-coordinate of that point.

solution.p: 1.5 hours

setup.pg-code: $gas = RadioButtons( ["At least 7.5 gallons", "At most 7.5 gallons", "At least 20 gallons.", "At most 240 gallons"], 1, );

statement.p: Leon forgot to reset his odometer after his last fill-up, but he thinks he has driven at least 150 miles. How much gas does he have left?
Show this on the graph.

hint.p: Locate 150 miles on the d-axis. What part of the axis represents "at least" 150 miles? Find the points on the graph with d-coordinates at least 150. What are the g-coordinates of those points?

solution.p: At most 7.5 gallon

statement.p: Find the intercepts of the graph of y=-9-\dfrac{3}{2}x \text{.} Enter each intercept as an ordered pair.
The x-intercept is .
The y-intercept is .

solution.p: We find the x-intercept by setting y=0 and solving for x to learn that x=-6\text{,} so the x-intercept is {\left(-6,0\right)}\text{.}
We find the y-intercept by setting x=0 and solving for y to learn that y=-9\text{,} so the y-intercept is {\left(0,-9\right)}\text{.}
